title: 105_s1755
content: The Act titled "Children's Health Preservation and Tobacco Advertising Compliance Act" disallows tax deductions for certain advertising, promotion, and marketing expenses related to tobacco product use. No deduction is allowed for advertising tobacco products in outdoor spaces or using human images or cartoons under the "Children's Health Preservation and Tobacco Advertising Compliance Act." The "Children's Health Preservation and Tobacco Advertising Compliance Act" prohibits the use of human images or cartoons in advertising tobacco products, as well as advertising on the internet and point of sale advertising, with exceptions for adult-only stores and tobacco outlets. The "Children's Health Preservation and Tobacco Advertising Compliance Act" restricts tobacco advertising, allowing only 2 point of sale ads per location and prohibiting agreements that limit retailers from displaying ads from other manufacturers. The "Children's Health Preservation and Tobacco Advertising Compliance Act" restricts tobacco advertising, allowing only 2 point of sale ads per location and prohibiting agreements that limit retailers from displaying ads from other manufacturers. Point of sale advertisements must be limited to 576 square inches, black letters on a white background, and not located near candy displays. Audio and video ads can be distributed to individuals over 18 at point of sale but cannot be played or viewed there. Additional restrictions include manufacturers not being allowed to use a non-tobacco product's name for a cigarette or smokeless tobacco product, except for products with names used before January 1, 1998. Advertising limitations are also in place for manufacturers, distributors, and retailers. Advertising limitations for tobacco products include restrictions on where manufacturers, distributors, and retailers can advertise, such as in newspapers, magazines, billboards, and point-of-sale promotional materials. The restrictions on advertising tobacco products include notifying the Secretary of Health and Human Services before using a new advertising medium not described in the regulations. The Secretary must make a determination within 30 days of receiving the notice. Additionally, no payment can be made for the placement of tobacco products in entertainment media. Restrictions on payment for placement of tobacco products in entertainment media and glamorization of tobacco products are outlined. No payment can be made for placement in television programs, movies, videos, or video games. Additionally, no payment can be made for promoting tobacco products through media appealing to individuals under 18 years old. Format and content requirements for labeling and advertising are also specified. Format and Content Requirements for Labeling and Advertising specify that tobacco product advertising must use black text on a white background, with exceptions for certain locations and adult publications. The regulations for advertising tobacco products in audio or video formats require compliance with specific guidelines. The regulations for advertising tobacco products in audio or video formats require compliance with specific guidelines, including limitations on music, sound effects, and visual elements. Additionally, there is a ban on marketing non-tobacco merchandise bearing tobacco brand names or logos. The regulations prohibit the marketing of non-tobacco items with tobacco brand elements, offering gifts in exchange for tobacco product purchases, and sponsoring events by tobacco manufacturers, distributors, or retailers. The regulations prohibit manufacturers, distributors, or retailers from sponsoring events using tobacco brand elements. However, they can sponsor events using their corporate name if registered before January 1, 1995, and not including tobacco brand elements. The regulations prohibit sponsorship of events using tobacco brand elements. However, events can be sponsored using the corporate name if registered before January 1, 1995, and without tobacco brand elements. The term 'brand' refers to a variety of tobacco products distinguished by various factors. The term 'brand' in tobacco products refers to varieties distinguished by factors like tobacco used, tar content, nicotine content, flavoring, size, filtration, and packaging. A 'distributor' is any person involved in furthering the distribution of tobacco products. 'Package' refers to the container in which tobacco products are offered for sale. 'Point of sale' is any location where tobacco products can be purchased. 'Point of sale advertising' includes all printed or graphical materials at the point of sale. A retailer is a person who sells tobacco products for personal consumption. Point of sale advertising includes materials bearing brand identification seen by customers where tobacco products are sold. Video refers to audiovisual works for public viewing.
